Although ammonia is a listed toxic substance, it is also a ubiquitous material, which is used by the surrounding farmers for fertilizer. Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.125 Exemptions ? Ammonia used as an agricultural nutrient, when held by farmers, is exempt from all provisions of this part (40 CFR 68).

III.    Facility Identification
The ConAgra facility is located at 4530 Mobile Highway in Montgomery, Alabama. The plant is a beef processor (meat grinder) and a ready-to-eat poultry facility.  The final products produced include hamburger patties and ready-to-eat poultry. The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There are two refrigeration systems onsite: the House System (System 1) and the Frigo System (System 2). The amount of ammonia present in the House refrigeration system is approximately 51,000 pounds, and the amount of ammonia present in the Frigo system is 14,000 pounds. The entire amount of ammonia in both systems is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. 

The House System has a high-pressure receiver that is located outside.  It is administratively controlled to hold 50-60% of the vessel?s capacity. The high-pressure receiver tank is not located near any other processes.  A high temperature recirculator vessel is also located outside near the high-pressure receiver.  It is administratively controlled to hold a maximum of 80% of its capacity. This high temperature recirculator tank is not located near any other processes. 

The Frigo system is a critical charge system and has no high-pressure receiver. Most of the ammonia in this system is contained in the intercooler, thermal siphon receiver and the accumulator, which are all located inside of a building.  The Intercooler can hold 80% of the

Frigo System?s charge.

IV.    Hazard Assessment ? Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)
While a catastrophic release is not expected to occur, as required by the Rule, Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios were evaluated to estimate the potential offsite consequences (i.e., offsite consequence analysis (OCA)) to the public or the environment from the potential accidental release of ammonia. 

Pursuant to the Rule, ?the greatest amount held in a single vessel, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity? was used. 

The worst-case toxic accidental release scenario is a catastrophic failure of the high temperature (approximately 26 psig and 12?F) ammonia recirculator, which is located outside and is administratively controlled to hold a maximum of 12,600 pounds (80-percent vessel capacity). 

Another worst-case toxic accidental release scenario was considered and is described as follows. The outside high pressure receiver (approximately 170 psig and 95?F) was evaluated.  It is larger than the high temperature ammonia receiver, but is administratively controlled to hold a maximum of 10,050 pounds (60-percent vessel capacity). It is located near the high temperature receiver, and both vessels are located approximately the same distance to the plant?s property boundary.

The intercooler in System 2 is administratively controlled to hold a maximum of 11,000 pounds of ammonia.  It has a temperature of 50?F and is maintained at 80 psig.  It is located inside of the building - the high-pressure receiver (for System 1) is located outside of the building along the same wall. 

 Worse case offsite consequence analyses were calculated for these three vessels.

 EPA?s Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration (EPA 550-B-00-006, May 2000) Exhibit 4-4, shows that under a worst-case release scenario for the high temperature ammonia recirculator ? whereby the entire 12,600 pound quantity of anhydrous ammonia is released in a 10-minute perio

d, the toxic endpoint distance is 1.5 miles. Under a worst-case release scenario for the high-pressure ammonia receiver ? whereby the entire 10,050 pound quantity of anhydrous ammonia is released in a 10-minute period, the toxic endpoint distance is 1.2 miles. Under a worst-case release scenario for the intercooler ? whereby the entire 11,000 pound quantity of anhydrous ammonia is released in a 10-minute period, the toxic endpoint distance is 0.9 miles. 

Since all three vessels are located near each other and are at the same approximate distance to the plant?s property boundary, the receptors are the same.  A release from the high temperature recirculator was selected as the worse case scenario as it contains the largest quantity of ammonia. The worst-case scenario for the high temperature recirculator encompasses all receptors affected by the worst-case scenarios for the vessels holding smaller quantities of ammonia.

The ERPG-2 airborne toxic endpoint concentration of 200 parts per million (ppm) or 0.14 mg/L is the maximum which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual?s ability to take protective action. Based upon year 2000 census data, the population within a radius of 1.5 miles is insert 5,573.

It should be noted that the worst-case scenario is an extremely unlikely event especially since most of the time, the ammonia is distributed within the piping of many refrigeration subsystems within the facility building ? and is not contained within this large vessel.

V.    Hazard Assessment ? Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)
An ARS was modeled for ammonia in the hazard assessment and assumes that a leak occurs in a pipe joint or weld. ?Guidance average? weather conditions including 3 meters per second wind speed and a D stability class at an ambient temperature of 25 degrees C were used. The simplified Berno

ulli equation was employed in the ARS OCA. Using a conservative pressure of 180 pounds per square inch (gauge) with a hole-diameter of up to 0.37 inches, the continuous release rate would be 300 pounds per minute, which would result in a 200-ppm toxic endpoint distance of 0.1 miles (Guidance Tables: Exhibits 4-5 and 4-6) in this urban setting. No mitigation measures were considered.

A small population group may be affected by the ARS due to the close proximity of commercial/office areas to the facility; however, the LandView Census estimator did not indicate any offsite receptors.

VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program. This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. Hygieneering, Inc. (Hygieneering) conducted an audit of the PSM program on February 28, 2003.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
?    Employee Participation ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program ensures employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  Employees at ConAgra have assisted in developing the initial PHA for the ammonia process as well as updating and revalidating the PHA every five years.  In addition, employees have assisted in the development of other PSM/RMP information such as the development of operating and preventative maintenance procedures.
?    Process Safety Information ? C

onAgra has developed a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of August 14, 2003.
?    Process Hazard Review ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough    to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program has been established to ensure PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and to ensure findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. An initial PHA study was conducted for the System 1 ammonia process on May 9, 1995 and was revalidated on July 9, 2003.  An initial PHA study was completed for the System 2 ammonia process on March 10, 2003.
?    Operating Procedures ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Operating procedures were initially developed when the ammonia process was installed. Annually, operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate. Operating Procedures for the ammonia process were last reviewed and updated as of November 24, 2003.
?    Training ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
?    Management of Change ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
?    Pre-Startup Review ?ConAgra

has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
?    Mechanical Integrity ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Preventative maintenance procedures have been established within written operating procedures, which were last updated as of November 24, 2003.  In addition, a preventative maintenance database application has been established to assist in documenting and tracking preventative maintenance activities.
?    Contractor Qualifications ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers? safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between ConAgra and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.
?    Incident Investigation ? ConAgra has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either resulted in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure also makes provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
?    Compliance Audit ?ConAgra has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that ConAgra?s PSM/RMP practices and procedures are ade

quate and are being followed.  The last compliance audit was conducted in February 28, 2003.
?    Hot Work Permits ? ConAgra has implemented the hot work program and developed a best management practice for hot work.

The following manuals were recently updated and completed for ConAgra Foods by Hygieneering for the facility?s ammonia process:  Process Safety Information Manual (December 5, 2003), Process Safety Management Manual (September 5, 2003), July 2003 Process Hazard Analysis, and the Standard Operating Procedures (November 24, 2003).  These documents are required as part of ConAgra Foods Risk Management Program.

The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:

?    Process safety information is provided to all employees upon hire and is accessible at all times.
?    In-depth process hazard analyses are completed every five years by qualified personnel using techniques approved under the PSM standard.
?    Written operating procedures (kept up-to-date) are used for training and guiding the work of operators.
?    Training is provided to all employees upon hire, and refresher training is given annually or upon request.
?    Operators, mechanics, and contractor personnel are qualified, trained and in the general hazards in the facility, and informed of any temporary situations affecting safety.
?    Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted to insure that conditions for safe operation have been satisfied prior to starting new or modified equipment.
?    A program is in place to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process, which includes written procedures, training requirements, equipment deficiency requests for employees, work orders, scheduled maintenance, and computerized documentation.
?    A hot work permit system assures that work is done safely and properly.
?    A management of change system is in place to ensure that changes are managed safely.
?    Incidents are investigated and ac

tions are taken as part of a continuous improvement effort.
?    Routine audits are conducted to assure that safe practices are being followed.

This systematic approach to process safety at ConAgra involves employees and strives for continuing improvements in overall safety. The training, qualifications, and safety awareness of our operations, maintenance, and management personnel are a key element in reducing and mitigating accidents.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include safety interlocks/alarms to prevent ammonia (1) overfilling (flooding) of various subsystem vessels; and (2) over-pressurization, whereby control valves fail ?open? to reduce and distribute system pressure. An ammonia detection sensor exists in the engine rooms for both of the ammonia systems.

ConAgra has a security surveillance program in place to deter theft, vandalism, and terrorism.

VII..    Five-Year Accident History
Based on discussions with plant personnel and review of available file information, the ConAgra Foods ? Foods Service Company facility (formerly, ConAgra - S & C Beef Processors Plant) has not had any accidental anhydrous ammonia releases, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years. 

VIII.    Emergency Response Program
ConAgra has an Emergency Response Plan (ERP), updated on January 1, 2004, to ensure that in the event of an emergency the personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. Response activities are coordinated with the Montgomery City / Montgomery County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), the City of Montgomery Fire Department and the City of Montgomery HAZMAT Team. This coordination effort includes providing the fire department with site diagrams and hazardous material information, meeting with fire department person

nel to discuss facility operations/processes, and periodic on-site inspections by fire department personnel.

The facility maintains an ERP on file at the plant. According to the ERP, facility employees are responsible for responding to accidental releases of ammonia. The plant employees are assisted by outside agencies and contractors as necessary. The plan includes annual training of all employees on evacuation procedures and emergency notification procedures. The plan also includes annual training for emergency response team members. It identifies the emergency coordinators, communication coordinators and alternates. In addition to the facility ERP, the plant will be included in a community emergency response plan developed by the Montgomery City / Montgomery County Local Emergency Planning Committee. ConAgra Foods also coordinates with the City of Montgomery Fire Department on emergency response activities. 

The facility has a windsock present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release.

Responders receive Hazwoper training through classroom instruction, on the job training and drills. Hazwoper training includes first responder awareness levels, first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training. Responder HAZWOPER training also includes procedures for using and maintaining emergency response equipment as required.

The facility's Onsite Incident Commander (Plant Manger) is responsible for notifying onsite emergency response personnel, emergency response contractors and local, state and federal agencies of releases. The Environmental Regulatory Supervisor is responsible for submitting written communication concerning releases to local, state and federal agencies.

The facility?s Evacuation Coordinator is responsible for coordinating site evacuation in the event of a release that requires evacuation.

The facility?s Emergency Response Plan is maintained onsite as part of the Risk Management Program.

X.    Spill Reporting / Environmental Release Procedures
In the event of a catastrophic release, call 911.

1.    Whenever there is any type of chemical release, the mechanic / technician on duty will immediately notify their supervisor. The supervisor will then notify the Incident Commander to determine whether the release is reportable or non-reportable. If the release is a reportable incident, the Refrigeration Manager and Environmental Regulatory Supervisor will immediatley be contactd by the Incident Commander.  The supervisor and mechanic / technician  must complete a chemical release incident report within 24 hours of the release. The report should be forwarded to the Refrigeration Manager and then given to the Environmental Regulatory Supervisor. The Environmental Regulatory Supervisor will keep the reports on file for a period of six years.

2.    If an ammonia release has a flow rate of 100 pounds or greater in a 24 period, the following steps should be taken:
a.    Immediately contact ConAgra Foods Onsite Incident Commander / Emergency Coordinator who will notify the appropriate state and federal agencies. The phone number for the Onsite Incident Commander is (334) 318-1118. If you cannot reach the Onsite Incident Commander, call the facility?s 24-hour emergency number at the onsite at (334) 288-8660. If no one can be reached at this number, contact ConAgra?s Corporate Director of Health and Safety at the following phone numbers: 

630-512-1529
630-750-2413
630-226-9435

If you cannot contact anyone at the above numbers, proceed to the next steps.

In the event of a

catastrophic release, call 911.

b.    The supervisor on the shift must notify the City of Montgomery Fire Department: (334-241-2400) and the Montgomery City / Montgomery County LEPC: (334) 241-2022 within 24 hours of the incident. When reporting the incident, the Emergency Notification Form must be completed. 

Only department supervisors are authorized to report releases (except in the event of a catastrophic release, in which case, call 911). Within 36 hours of the first phone call a second phone call must be made to the City of Montgomery Fire Department (334-241-2400) and to the Montgomery City / Montgomery County LEPC: (334) 241-2022 to advise them further on the status of the release. At this time a second Emergency Notification Form must be completed. 
c.    The Onsite Incident Commander / Emergency Coordinator (or supervisor/department manager as directed by the Onsite Incident Commander / Emergency Coordinator) should also contact the Alabama Department of Environmental Management after calling the City of Montgomery Fire Department to put them on alert. The phone number for the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, Emergency Response Division, is (334) 271-7700. The reporter will provide this agency with the same information as provided to the fire department.  He will note that the call was made and list the contact person on the Emergency Notification Form.
d.    The National Emergency Response Center must be notified. The phone number for the National Emergency Response Center is 1-800-424-8802. Again the reporter will note on the emergency notification form that the call was made and will list the contact name on the Emergency Notification Form.
e.    Copies of all Emergency Notification Forms should be given to the Environmental Coordinator to keep on file for a period of six years.

3.    When an ammonia release is of the magnitude of 100 pounds or greater in a 24-hour period, the supervisor/engineer on shift should immediately notify the Refrigeration M

anager or the Environmental Regulatory Supervisor who will initiate putting the Emergency Response Plan into effect. Procedures for activating the Emergency Response Plan are set forth in the Emergency Response Plan.

4.    Within 24 hours of a release equal to or exceeding 100 pounds in a 24-hour period, the National Response Center, the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, Emergency Response Division, and the LEPC must be notified.  The Refrigeration Manager or the Environmental Regulatory Supervisor will sign copies of the Emergency Notification Report. The report should also be copied to ConAgra Foods Environmental Regulatory Supervisor.

XI.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of ConAgra?s operations. ConAgra recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that audit. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for ConAgra. In addition to the facility ERP, the plant will be included in a community emergency response plan developed by the Montgomery County Local Emergency Planning Committee. 

New administrative procedures: On an annual basis, ConAgra management including the Plant Manger, Maintenance Manager, Safety Manager, Refrigeration Manager and the Environmental Regulatory Supervisor will review the LEPC?s Community Emergency Response Plan and will certify that these documents have been reviewed and discussed with the LEPC, the Montgomery City / County Fire Department and the City of Montgomery HAZMAT Team. Additionally, on an annual basis the following guidance documents will be reviewed by the ConAgra management listed above:

(1)    EPA 550-F-01-005 LEPC?s and Deliberate Releases
(2)    EPA-F-00-005 Anhydrous Ammonia Theft
(3)    EPA 550-F-01-009 Hazards of Ammonia Release at Ammonia Refrigeration Facilities (Update)
(4)    EPA 550-F-97-002a Rupture Hazard of Pressure Vessels

XII.    Management Program
The owner or operator of a sta

tionary source with processes subject to Program 2 and 3 must develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This includes assigning a qualified person (or position) to have overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals need to be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  The Emergency Chain of Command identified in the Emergency Response Plan developed for the ConAgra Foods Montgomery Plant outlines this organization, and assigns specific responsibilities to each position.  Additionally, Spencer Harris is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
